prefix: Approach the following question the way someone with a PhD in mathematics would.
problem_prompt:
Approach the following question the way someone with a PhD in mathematics would. If $a,b,c$ are non-negative integers less than $7$ such that \begin{align*}
a+2b+3c&\equiv 0\pmod 7,\\
2a+3b+c&\equiv 4\pmod 7,\\
3a+b+2c&\equiv 4\pmod 7,
\end{align*}then determine the remainder when $abc$ is divided by $7$.
solution:
Adding the three congruences gives \begin{align*}
&6(a+b+c)\equiv 8\pmod 7\\
\implies& -(a+b+c) \equiv 1\pmod 7.
\end{align*}Adding this to each of the congruences yields \begin{align*}
b+2c&\equiv 1\pmod 7,\\
a+2b&\equiv 5\pmod 7,\\
2a+c&\equiv 5\pmod 7.
\end{align*}Substituting $b\equiv 1-2c\pmod 7$ into the second one gives \begin{align*}
&a+2(1-2c)\equiv 5\pmod 7\\
\implies&a-4c\equiv 3\pmod 7\\
\implies&4c-a\equiv 4\pmod 7\\
\implies&8c-2a\equiv 8\pmod 7\\
\implies&c-2a\equiv 1\pmod 7.
\end{align*}Adding this to $2a+c\equiv 5\pmod 7$ results in $2c\equiv 6\pmod 7\implies c\equiv 3\pmod 7$. Finally \begin{align*}
&b\equiv 1-2c\equiv 1-2\cdot 3\equiv 2\pmod 7,\\
&a\equiv 5-2b\equiv 5-2\cdot 2\equiv 1\pmod 7.
\end{align*}Thus, $abc\equiv 1\cdot 2\cdot 3\equiv \boxed{6}$.

Let's first rewrite the given system of congruences in matrix form:
$$\begin{pmatrix} 1 & 2 & 3 \\ 2 & 3 & 1 \\ 3 & 1 & 2 \end{pmatrix} \begin{pmatrix} a \\ b \\ c \end{pmatrix} \equiv \begin{pmatrix} 0 \\ 4 \\ 4 \end{pmatrix} \pmod{7}.$$

We can call the coefficient matrix $A$ and the vector of variables $x$ and the vector on the right side $b$:
$$Ax \equiv b \pmod{7}.$$

Now, we know that in order to be able to solve this system, $A$ must be invertible modulo $7$. We can calculate the determinant of $A$ by only considering the remainders modulo $7$:
$$\text{det}(A) = \text{det}\begin{pmatrix} 1 & 2 & 3 \\ 2 & 3 & 1 \\ 3 & 1 & 2 \end{pmatrix} = (1\cdot 3\cdot 2 + 2\cdot 1\cdot 3 + 3\cdot 2\cdot 1) - (3\cdot 3\cdot 3 + 1\cdot 2\cdot 2 + 2\cdot 1\cdot 1) = -7 \equiv 0 \pmod{7}.$$

Since the determinant is zero, $A$ is not invertible. This means we won't be able to directly solve for $x$ as we could in a regular system of equations. However, we can still find a solution for $x$ modulo $7$ by computing the reduced row-echelon form of $A$ augmented with $b$:
$$\left[\begin{array}{ccc|c} 1 & 2 & 3 & 0 \\ 2 & 3 & 1 & 4 \\ 3 & 1 & 2 & 4 \end{array}\right].$$

The reduced row-echelon form of this augmented matrix simplifies to:
$$\left[\begin{array}{ccc|c} 1 & 0 & 0 & 4 \\ 0 & 1 & 0 & 1 \\ 0 & 0 & 1 & 4 \end{array}\right].$$

This corresponds to the solution $a \equiv 4 \pmod{7}$, $b \equiv 1 \pmod{7}$, $c \equiv 4 \pmod{7}$. Therefore, $abc \equiv 4\cdot1\cdot4 \equiv 16 \equiv 2 \pmod{7}.$

Hence, the remainder when $abc$ is divided by $7$ is $\boxed{2}$.
